alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. 1 of the best thing we do at the first course, my wife love it, is gravlax. And the gravlax, Here I'm doing it with salmon. And I call that an aspen gravlax. I'm cutting it thin, well, as thin as you can, really. Even if it's a bit thicker, it doesn't really matter. Notice that here I have the belly of the salmon. I think The belly of the salmon is probably the fattiest and 1 of the best. So I'm serving about an ounce and a half, 2 ounce maybe per person at the most for 2. And here we are. So I cut it into thin slice this way. And then let's say for 2 here, I have 2 plate. Put your salt right on top of it here. And be generous with the salt, it needs salt here. And then I'm putting my salmon right there. Maybe this 1 here. And a little bit of salt on top and pepper. I should have put pepper underneath as well as I do here, that's it. So what I do sometimes when I have a party or 5, 6 people or more, so I do that ahead. I bring those things ahead. I do all my portion ahead like this. Salt on top. And then I put a piece of plastic wrap on top of it. The other plate, another piece of plastic wrap. The other plate, 6 or 8 people. I put that in the refrigerator. I can do that 233 hours, even a day ahead. It's perfectly fine. When you're ready to serve, then you put your garnish in it. And the garnish can be a lot of different thing. In that case here, I have a few capers. So I'm going to put capers, caper goes well with it. I have onion and those are, those are of course Vidalia onion. I mean, onion which are mild and so forth. You can put more stuff, you can put radish, I put in there, cucumber, Stuff like this. I have a bit of a scallion green here. Maybe I'll put this. And I go usually to my garden, see the type of herb that I have. I happen to have a little bit of basil here. So I will put the basil shredded, but I will prepare all of my garnish. You see, and you get your salmon out of the refrigerator, all cured, you spread out all that top on top and you serve. And it's a great way of doing it. Always a little bit of olive oil around like this. Beautiful. Serve that with a black bread or a crunchy baguette. And if you serve lemon or lime, don't put it on top now because it's going to eat the protein in the salmon that it's looking, it kind of cook it. So you put it on the side to serve it. When you serve like a lemon or a lime, don't cut it in the center, Cut it just off the center. See, you have a nicer cut here without the seed. And then that the way you put it around to press it. And here is our salmon assam gravlax. Bon appetit and happy cooking.

paragraphs.transcript:
Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home. 1 of the best thing we do at the first course, my wife love it, is gravlax. And the gravlax, Here I'm doing it with salmon. And I call that an aspen gravlax. I'm cutting it thin, well, as thin as you can, really.

Even if it's a bit thicker, it doesn't really matter. Notice that here I have the belly of the salmon. I think The belly of the salmon is probably the fattiest and 1 of the best. So I'm serving about an ounce and a half, 2 ounce maybe per person at the most for 2. And here we are.

So I cut it into thin slice this way. And then let's say for 2 here, I have 2 plate. Put your salt right on top of it here. And be generous with the salt, it needs salt here. And then I'm putting my salmon right there.

Maybe this 1 here. And a little bit of salt on top and pepper. I should have put pepper underneath as well as I do here, that's it. So what I do sometimes when I have a party or 5, 6 people or more, so I do that ahead. I bring those things ahead.

I do all my portion ahead like this. Salt on top. And then I put a piece of plastic wrap on top of it. The other plate, another piece of plastic wrap. The other plate, 6 or 8 people.

I put that in the refrigerator. I can do that 233 hours, even a day ahead. It's perfectly fine. When you're ready to serve, then you put your garnish in it. And the garnish can be a lot of different thing.

In that case here, I have a few capers. So I'm going to put capers, caper goes well with it. I have onion and those are, those are of course Vidalia onion. I mean, onion which are mild and so forth. You can put more stuff, you can put radish, I put in there, cucumber, Stuff like this.

I have a bit of a scallion green here. Maybe I'll put this. And I go usually to my garden, see the type of herb that I have. I happen to have a little bit of basil here. So I will put the basil shredded, but I will prepare all of my garnish.

You see, and you get your salmon out of the refrigerator, all cured, you spread out all that top on top and you serve. And it's a great way of doing it. Always a little bit of olive oil around like this. Beautiful. Serve that with a black bread or a crunchy baguette.

And if you serve lemon or lime, don't put it on top now because it's going to eat the protein in the salmon that it's looking, it kind of cook it. So you put it on the side to serve it. When you serve like a lemon or a lime, don't cut it in the center, Cut it just off the center. See, you have a nicer cut here without the seed. And then that the way you put it around to press it.

And here is our salmon assam gravlax. Bon appetit and happy cooking.

sentences.text: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin and I'm cooking at home.
1 of the best thing we do at the first course, my wife love it, is gravlax.
And the gravlax, Here I'm doing it with salmon.
And I call that an aspen gravlax.
I'm cutting it thin, well, as thin as you can, really.
Even if it's a bit thicker, it doesn't really matter.
Notice that here I have the belly of the salmon.
I think The belly of the salmon is probably the fattiest and 1 of the best.
So I'm serving about an ounce and a half, 2 ounce maybe per person at the most for 2.
And here we are.
So I cut it into thin slice this way.
And then let's say for 2 here, I have 2 plate.
Put your salt right on top of it here.
And be generous with the salt, it needs salt here.
And then I'm putting my salmon right there.
Maybe this 1 here.
And a little bit of salt on top and pepper.
I should have put pepper underneath as well as I do here, that's it.
So what I do sometimes when I have a party or 5, 6 people or more, so I do that ahead.
I bring those things ahead.
I do all my portion ahead like this.
Salt on top.
And then I put a piece of plastic wrap on top of it.
The other plate, another piece of plastic wrap.
The other plate, 6 or 8 people.
I put that in the refrigerator.
I can do that 233 hours, even a day ahead.
It's perfectly fine.
When you're ready to serve, then you put your garnish in it.
And the garnish can be a lot of different thing.
In that case here, I have a few capers.
So I'm going to put capers, caper goes well with it.
I have onion and those are, those are of course Vidalia onion.
I mean, onion which are mild and so forth.
You can put more stuff, you can put radish, I put in there, cucumber, Stuff like this.
I have a bit of a scallion green here.
Maybe I'll put this.
And I go usually to my garden, see the type of herb that I have.
I happen to have a little bit of basil here.
So I will put the basil shredded, but I will prepare all of my garnish.
You see, and you get your salmon out of the refrigerator, all cured, you spread out all that top on top and you serve.
And it's a great way of doing it.
Always a little bit of olive oil around like this.
Beautiful.
Serve that with a black bread or a crunchy baguette.
And if you serve lemon or lime, don't put it on top now because it's going to eat the protein in the salmon that it's looking, it kind of cook it.
So you put it on the side to serve it.
When you serve like a lemon or a lime, don't cut it in the center, Cut it just off the center.
See, you have a nicer cut here without the seed.
And then that the way you put it around to press it.
And here is our salmon assam gravlax.
Bon appetit and happy cooking.
